body.head:
Forest Leaves
Ethiopia*
body.annotation: Harper revised this poem for her 1854 Poems on Miscellaneus Subjects. It was reprinted in Augues 24, 1855 issue of Frederick Douglass' Paper.

lg.l: Yes,Ethiopia, yet shall stretch

Her bleeding hands abroad,Psalm 68:31.In the Old Testament, Ethiopia refers not to the modern kingdom of Ethiopia, but to an ancient Nubia, the modern Sudan. In its nineteenth-century usage, the term "Ethiopian" referred more generally to people of African descent, rather than to the region or nation of Ethiopiamore specifically. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, the use of "Ethiop" to refer to " a black or dark-skinned person; a black African" dates to as early as the fourteenth century. This use was also prominent in other African American writing, as in that of Harper's predecessor, Phillis Wheatley, who refers to herself as "An Ethiop" inTo the University of Cambridge, in New England"(1773)
Her cry of agony shall reach
The burning throne of God
The tyrant's yoke from off her neck,
His fetters from her soul,
The mighty hand of Godshall break,
And spurn their vile control.
Redeem'dRedeemedfrom dust and freed from chains
Her sons shall lift their eyes
From cloud capt hills and verdantverdant: green with grass, rich vegetationplains
Shall shouts of triumph rise.
Upon her dark desparing brow
Shall play a smile of peace
For God hath bent unto her woe
And bade her sorrows cease.
'NeathBeneath sheltering vines and stately palms
Shall laughing children play,
And aged sires with joyous psalms,
Shall gladden every day.
Secure by night, and blest by day
Shall pass her happy hours
Nor human tigers hunt for prey
Within her peaceful bowers.
Then Ethiopia, stretch, Oh Stretch
Thy bleeding hands abroad,
Thy cry of agony shall reach
And find redress from God.

lg.l: Bring forth the balance, let the weights be gold,
We'd know the worth of a deathless soul;
Bring rubies and jems from every mine,
With the wealth of the ocean, land and clime.
Bring the joys of the glad green earth,
Its playful simles and careless mirth;
The dews of youth, and flushes of health,
Bring! Oh Bring! the wide world's wealth
Bring the rich and radiant gems of thought
From the mines and deeps of knowledge brought;
Bring glowing words and ponderous lore
Search heaven and earth's arcanaarcana: secrets or mysteries o'erover
Bring the fairest, brightest rolls of fame,
Unwritten with a deed of guilt or shame;
Bring honor's guerdon,guerdon: reward and victory's crown,
Robes of pride, and laurels of renown.
We've brought the wealth of every mine,
We've ransack'dransacked ocean, land clime,
And caught the joyous smiles away
From the prattling babe to the sire grey.
We've brought the names of the noble dead
With those who in their footsteps tread;
Here are wreaths of pride and gems of thought
From the battle field and study brought.
Heap high the gems, pile up the gold,
Heavy's the weight of a deathless soul;
Make room for all the wealth of earth
Its honors, joys, and careless mirth.
Leave me a niche for the rolls of fame
For precious indeed is a spotless name,
For the wreaths, the robes and gems of thought,
Let an empty place in the scale be sought.

body.head: Page 5

lg.l: With care we've adjusted balance and scale
Futile our efforts we've seen them fail;
Lighter than dust is the wealth of earth
Weigh'dWeighedin the scales with immortal worth
Could we drag the sun from its golden carcar:chariot
To lay in this balance with ev'ryevery star,
T'wouldIt would darken the day and obscure the night,
But the weight of the balance would still be light.

body.head: "THAT BLESSED HOPE"*
body.annotation: Titus 2:13. Watkins revised this poem for her 1854 Poems on Miscellaneous Subjects.

lg.l: Oh touch it not that hope so blest
Which cheers the fainting heart,
And points it to the coming rest
Where sorrow has no part.
Tear from heart each worldly prop,
Unbind each earthly string;
But to this blest and glorious hope,
Oh let my spirit cling.
It cheer'dcheeredamid the days of old
Each holy patriach's breast,
It was an anchor to their souls,
Upon it let me rest.
When wand'ringwandering in the dens and caves,
In goat and sheep skins drest,
Apeel'dApeeled* and scatter'dscattered people learn'dlearned
lg.annotation: peeled: without covering; beggarly, wretched. The line reads “A peel’d” in both editions of Poems on Miscellaneous Subjects.
lg.l: To know this hope was blest
Help me to love this blessed hope;
My heart's a fragile thing;
Will you not nerve and bear it up
Aroung this hope to cling.
Help amid this world of strife
To long for Christ to reign,
That when he brings the crown of life
I may that crown obtian.

Yearnings for Home.*

lg.l: Oh let me go I'm weary here
And fevers scorch my brain,
I long to feel my native air
Breath o'erover each burning vein.
I long once more to see
My home among the distant hills,
To breathe amid the melody
Of murmering brooks and rills.rills: small streams
My home is where eternal snow
Round threat'ningthreatening craters sleep,
Where streamlets murmer soft and low
And playful cascades leap.
Tis where glad scenes shall meet
My weary, longing eye;
Where rocks and Alpine forest greet
The bright ceruleancerulean: deep-blue in color sky.
Your scenes are bright I know,
But there my mother pray'dprayed
Her cot is lowly, but I go
To die beneath its shade.
For, Oh I know she'll cling
'RoundAround me her treasur'dtreasured long,
My sisters too will sing
Each lov'dloved familiar song.
They'll soothe my fever'dfevered brow,
As in departed hours,
And spread around my dying couch
The brightest, fairest flowers.
Then let me go I'm weary here
And fevers scorch my brain,
I long to feel my native air.

body.head: Haman and Mordecai.Esther 3:1-7:10. Mordecai is a relative and guardian of Esther, who becomes queen when she marries King Ahasuerus (Xerxes 1 of Persia). Haman, the grand vizier, is infurieted that Mordecai, a Jew, refuses to bow to do him obeisance on religious grounds. Haman therefore plots not only to have Mordecai killed, but to exterminate all Jews in the Persian Empire.Queen Esther, who is herself Jewish, informs the king of Mordecai's service to him and Haman's plot and petitions him to save the lives of her people. Haman throws himself upon Esther's couch to plead with her for his own life, but the king takes this as an assault. Ahasuerus ultimately has Haman hanged on the gallows that Haman had prepared for Mordecai. Mordecai is appointed grand vizier and the king gives the Jews permission to slaughter their enemies. This deliverance of Persian Jews from Haman's plot establishes the Jewish feast of Purim.

And he heeded not the crowd.

'Twas as the light'ninglightning ere the storm
Hath swepth in fury by.
On noble Mordecai alone,
He scorn'dscorned to lay his hand;
But sought an edict from the throne
'Gainstagainst all the captivt band.
For full of pride and wrate
To his fell purpose true,

Then woman's voice arose
In deep impassion'dimpassioned prayer,

body.head: Ruth and Niomi.*
body.annotation: Naomi moves from Bethlehem to Moab with her husband and sons, one of whom marries Ruth, a Moabite woman. Naomi’s husband and sons (including Ruth’s husband) die and Naomi prepares to return to Bethlehem. Ruth chooses to remain with her mother-in-law and works to support her, rather than returning to her own people. Ruth’s marriage to Mahlon is considered a “mixed” marriage because Ruth is a Moabite and Naomi and her family are Jewish. This makes Ruth’s decision to remain with her mother-in-law even more significant (Ruth 1:9-22). Ruth goes on to marry Boaz, a wealthy landowner and relation of Naomi’s late husband. King David is one of their descendants (Ruth 2:1-4:22). Watkins revised this poem for the 1857 edition of Poems on Miscellaneous Subjects.

lg.l: Turn my daughters full of woe,
Is my heart so sad and lone,
Leave me, children, I would go
To my lov'dloved and distant home.
From my bosom death has torn,
Husband, children, all my stay;
Left me not a single one
For my life's declining day.
Want and wo surround my way,
Grief and famine where I tread;
In my native land they say
God is giving Jacob his bread.
Niomi ceased, her daughters wept,
Their yearning hearts were fill'dfilled,
Falling upon her wither'dwithered neck
Their grief and tears distill'ddistilled.
Like rain upon a blighted tree
The tears of Orpah fell,
Kissing the pale and quiv'ringquivering lip,
She breath'dbreathed her sad farwell.
But Ruth stood up, on her brow
There lay a heavenly calm,
And from her lips came soft and low
Words like a holy charm.
I will not leave thee, on thy brow
Are lines of sorrow, age and care,
Thy form is bent, they step is slow,
Thy bosom stricken, lone and sear.
Thy failing lamp is growing dim,
It's flame is flick'ringflickering past,
I will not leave thee withering
'NeathBeneath stearn afflictions blast.
When thy heart and home were glad,
I freely shar'dshared thy joyous lot
And now the heart is lone and sad,
Cease to entreat I'll leave thee not.
Oh if a lofty palace proud
Thy future home shall be,
Where sycophants* around thee crowd
lg.annotation: sycophant: a person who is flattering influential people in order to gain certain advantages
lg.l: I'll share that home with thee.
And if on earth the humblest spot
Thy future home shall prove,
I'll bring into thy lowly cot
The wealth of woman's love
However drear, earth has no lot
My spirit shrinks to share with thee,
Then mother, dear entreat me not
To turn from following after thee.
Go where thou wilt my steps are there,
Our path in life is one,
Thou hast no lot I will not share
Till life itself be done.
My country and my home for thee
I freely, willingly resign;
Thy people shall my people be,
Thy God he shall be mine.
Then mother, dear, entreat me not
To turn from following thee,
My heart is mov'dmoved to share thy lot
What e'erever that lot may be.

body.head: To a Missionary

lg.l: Joy, joy! unto the heathen,
Unfurl each snowy sail,
And waft the breath of prayer
On ev'ryevery breeze and gale.
Spread, spread your sails with mercy

As you plough the trackless,This line seems to be missing a word that would retain the rhyme and meter of the poem's other stanzas. Perhaps "trackless deep" is intended, as many writers of the period used that formulation to refer to the sea. The American poet Lydia H. Sigourney, for example, uses the phrase in Traits of the Aborigines of America(1822),"To a Fragment of Cotton"(1841), and "Sorrow as on the Sea"(1854).
And at your stern and helm
Shall God a vigil keep.
You're frighte with rich blessings,
You've glorious things to tell,
Your tidings are salvation

Your theme Immanuel.Immanuel, from the Hebrew meaning "God is with us" or "may God be with us." The prophet Isaiah announces the birth of a child with the name (Isaiah 7:10-17). Christians would later take the name to predict the virgin birth of the Messiah, Jesus Christ (Matthew 1:22).
Heathen minds by sin degraded,
Captives 'neathbeneath the tempter's sway,
Shall from their moral vision
Have the darkness chas'dchased away
'Neathbeneath bamboo hut and palm tree
Shall prayer like incense rise,
An oblationoblation: making a religious offering to God or god; a holy gift offered at an alter or shrine pure and holy
To the God of earth and skies.
He who from the fiery pillar
Guided once a pilgrim train,
Shall protect you by his power
As you sweep across the main.
More faithful than the needle
Pointing constant to the pole,
Shall the God of love be with you
When the darkest tempests roll.
God speed on your journey,
May his presence and his power
Be your stay in grief and trial
And the joy of every hour.

body.head: The Dying Christian*
body.annotation: Harper revised this poem for her 1854 Poems on Miscellaneous Subjects.

lg.l: The light was faintly streaming
Within a darken'ddarkened room,
Where a woman, faint and feeble
Was sinking to the tomb
"The silver cord"* was loosened,
We knew that she must die,
We read the mournful token
In the dimness of her eye.
We read it in the radiance
That lit her pallid cheek,
And the quivering of the feeble lip
Too faint its joys to speak.
We read in the glorious flash
Of strange unearthly light,
That ever and non would dash
The dimness from her sight.
And in the thoughts of living fire
Learn'dLearned from God's encamping band,
Her words seem'dseemed like a holy lyre
Tun'dTuned in the spirit land.
Meet, oh meet me in the kingdom,
Said our lov'dloved and dying one,
I long to be with Jesus,
I am going, going home.
Like a child oppress'doppressed with slumber
She calmly sank to rest,
With her trust in the Redeemer
And her head upom his breast.
She faded from our vision
Like a thing of love and light,
But we feel she lives forever
A spirit pure and bright.

body.head: A Dream

lg.l: I had a dream, a varied dream,*
lg.annotation: This line also opens one of Harper’s later poems, “Fishers of Men,” which was published in the 1886 edition of Sketches of Southern Life.
lg.l: A dream of joy and dread;
Before me rose the judgement scene
For God has raised the dead.
Each waiting one lifted his head
Rejoic'dRejoiced to see him nigh,
And erth cast out her sainted dead
To meet him in the sky
Before his white and burning throne
A countless throng did stand;
Whilst Christ confess'sconfessed his own,
Whose names were on his hand
I hand a dream, a varied dream,
A dream of joy and dread;
Beofre me rose the judgment scene
For God had rais'draised the dead.
Oh for an angel's hand to paint
The terrors of that day,
When God in vengance for his saints
Girded* himself with wrath to slay.
lg.annotation: girded: to encircle a person or part of a body with a belt

lg.l: But, oh the terror, grief, and dread,
Tongue can't describe or pen portray;
When from their graves arose the dead,
Guilty to meet the judgment day.
As sudden as the lightning's flash
Across the sky doth sweep,
Earth's kingdom's were in pieces dash'ddashed,
And waken'dwakened from their guilty sleep.
I heard the agonizing cry,
Ye rocks and mountains on us fall,
And hide us from the Judge's eye
But rocks and mounts fled from the call
I saw the guilty ruin'druined host
Standing before the burning throne,
The ruin'druined, lost forever lost,
Whom God in wrath refus'drefused to own.

body.head: An Acrostic*
body.annotation: An acrostic is a poem in which certain letters in each line (often the first letters) spell out a word or phrase.

lg.l: Angels bright that hover o'erover thee,
Deem thee an object of their care;
Ever watchful they surround thee,
Lending aid when danger's near.
May this life, this guarded, sister
Always feel thy Saviour near
Render him thy heart's devotion-
Trust his goodness, seek his care;
In these vales of grief and sorrow,
Nought shall harm while God is near.

body.head: The Presentiment

lg.l: There's something strangely thrills my breast,
And fills it with a deep unrest,--
It is not grief, it is not pain
Nor wish to live the past again
'Tis something which I scarce can tell,
And yet I know, and feel it well;
Thro'through ev'ryevery vein it seems to run,
And whispers life will soon be done.
It comes in accents soft and low,
Like bright streamlets crystal flow,
It whispers, lingers round my heart,
And tells me I must soon depart
I felt it when the glow of life
Was warm upon my cheek,
In mournful cadence to my heart.
It solemnly did speak.
I felt it when a fearful strife
Was preying on my heart,
It told me from the cares of life,
I quickly must depart.
I felt it when my cheek grew pale,
By cares I could'nt could not repress;
It whisper'dwhispered to my wearried soul.
This earth is not your rest.
